It outsources what it makes, and what's really interesting about IKEA is that many of us think, well, you know, we don't go to Wal-Mart, we don't go to discount stores, but we'll go to IKEA, and that's why I wanted to go to Sweden and see how it worked.

But what I learned there was that IKEA designs to a price, which is really kind of a strange idea.
They set a price for, say, a table and chairs for $100, they design it, they have a team of expert designers who do a beautiful job of designing these things.
But then they squeeze their suppliers to - really to the limit to get these products at the lowest, lowest possible price.
And what that means is, of course, inevitably, they cut corners.
They cut corners in terms of the labor they use.
